p: The prevalence of feeding by the weevils differed (RM ANOVA, p < 0.0001) among the tree species ( Figure 1 and Figure 2). During the first two experimental weeks the preferred food source was P. abies. From the third week onwards, weevils started to prefer P. menziesii and seedlings of this species sustained the most damage. The mean bark area consumed per seedling was 440.8 ± 147.9 mm 2. The second most preferred host was P. abies (226.8 ± 72.31 mm 2). For nearly the entire experiment, weevils preferred L. decidua over P. sylvestris. However, damages on P. sylvestris dramatically increased during the last week. At the end of experiment mean debarked area reached 181.2 ± 31.77 mm 2 on P. sylvestris and 161.2 ± 41.10 mm 2 on L. decidua. Coniferous species suffering the least damage was A. alba. The mean area consumed per seedling was 76.8 ± 62.56 mm 2. B. pendula was the least preferred source of food. Damage was registered only at the last week of experiment in one cage and mean damaged area reached 5.2 ± 11.63 mm 2 ( Figure 1 and Figure 2).
